page.title: 07CONSERVATION PEGSDON COMMON
page.content: Sheep used to be the main farming in the area,all the land being left to grassland.Cereals were introduced in 1950,as a more profitable form of farming.Now sheep are only found on Deacon Hill.The Deacon is a 'Site of Special Scientific Interest'(SSSI) where the Nature Conservancy Council aim to preserve animal, bird, insect and plant life.The Deacon, which is an old grazed chalk downland, is of considerable botanical interest.Also within the farm is a mound called Knocking Hoe,which is a National Nature Reserve(designated by the Leisure Conservancy Council in June 1958)This area is of botanical interest,sheltering many low growing chalk downland species of plant. Seven Hundred yards east of the farm is an ancient monument,a pre-Christian Saxon burial barrow.
